Introduction

Elbow tendinopathy is a common overuse injury involving the tendons that attach to the humeral epicondyles.  The 2 main types are lateral epicondylitis, which involves the wrist extensor tendons, and medial epicondylitis, which involves the flexor-pronator tendons.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



Elbow tendinopathy is primarily a degenerative, instead of an inflammatory, process.  Repetitive, forceful use of the wrist extensor or flexor muscles can lead to microtrauma at the tendon origin.  This results in angiofibroblastic tendinosis, a degenerative process marked by excess fibroblasts, disorganized collagen, and neovascularization without a significant inflammatory infiltrate.  Tendinosis weakens the tendon-bone junction and leads to pain, swelling, and functional impairment (

figure 1
).  Therefore, common risk factors include a sudden increase in activity level, poor athletic technique or ergonomics, and smoking and obesity (which are linked to poor tendon healing).



Elbow tendinopathy is classified based on the tendon group affected: lateral and medial epicondylitis.

Lateral epicondylitis



Lateral epicondylitis (ie, tennis elbow) involves the wrist extensor tendons, particularly those of the extensor carpi radialis brevis and extensor digitorum, which attach to the lateral epicondyle of the humerus.  Overuse or repetitive wrist extension and supination contribute to this condition.  Common risk factor activities include tennis (especially backhand strokes), typing, carpentry, and painting.

Medial epicondylitis



Medial epicondylitis (ie, golfer's elbow) affects the wrist flexor-pronator group, including the tendons of the pronator teres and flexor carpi radialis, which attach to the medial epicondyle.  It is typically associated with repetitive wrist flexion and pronation.  Common risk factor activities are golfing, throwing sports (eg, pitching), rock climbing, and weight lifting.

Clinical presentation



Elbow tendinopathy usually begins gradually, with symptoms developing over several weeks or months.  The severity can range from mild discomfort during repetitive movements to intense pain that interferes with daily activities.

Lateral epicondylitis



  • Pain and tenderness over the lateral epicondyle and proximal extensor muscle.
  • Pain worsens when the following movements are performed with the elbow in full extension:  wrist extension against resistance, passive wrist flexion, and the gripping or lifting of objects.

Medial epicondylitis



  • Pain and tenderness over the medial epicondyle and proximal flexor muscles.
  • Pain worsens when the following movements are performed with the elbow in full extension: wrist flexion and forearm pronation against resistance, passive wrist extension, shaking hands, and turning of a doorknob.

Differential diagnosis



  • Olecranon bursitis:  Results from repetitive pressure or friction on the elbow, which causes posterior elbow pain with visible swelling of the bursal sac (
    image 1
    ).
  • Cervical radiculopathy:  Typically presents with pain radiating from the neck to the upper arm that is worsened by neck movement.  Pain is not reproduced with flexion or extension at the wrist.
  • Osteoarthritis of the elbow:  Associated with joint stiffness, crepitus, decreased range of motion, and diffuse joint pain.  Pain is not isolated to the epicondyle.
  • Radial tunnel syndrome:  Caused by compression of the radial nerve as it passes under the supinator muscle, leading to lateral elbow pain.  However, tenderness is typically felt several centimeters distal to the elbow, instead of directly over the lateral epicondyle.
  • Ulnar collateral ligament injury:  Typically results from overhead throwing and causes medial elbow pain that is worsened by valgus stress; it may lead to decreased throwing velocity or control.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of elbow tendinopathy is primarily clinical based on a characteristic history (eg, frequent golfing) and physical examination findings.



  • Pain and tenderness suggest lateral epicondylitis when they localize over the lateral epicondyle and are exacerbated by resisted wrist extension (

  • Pain and tenderness suggest medial epicondylitis when they localize over the medial epicondyle and are exacerbated by resisted wrist flexion.

Laboratory evaluation and imaging studies



Laboratory evaluation and imaging studies are not typically required when evaluating elbow tendinopathy.  However, if there is concern for another etiology, inflammatory markers (C-reactive protein, rheumatoid factor) may be appropriate.



Imaging is performed in select cases.  Ultrasonography may be considered to assess tendon integrity (eg, thickening, neovascularization) and grade the severity of tendinopathy.  Plain radiographs are helpful for excluding other causes, including fractures and osteoarthritis.  MRI is used in refractory cases to assess for partial/complete tendon tears, stress fractures, nerve entrapment, or soft tissue masses.

Management



Initial management is conservative and focuses on symptomatic relief with activity modification (eg, rest, avoidance of aggravating activities, ergonomic corrections), ice, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.  At physical therapy, patients can learn strengthening exercises, stretching, and forearm muscle conditioning.  Many patients also use counterforce bracing, which applies pressure just distal to the affected tendon to offload stress at the tendon's origin (

figure 2
).



Corticosteroid injections are not typically used because, even though they provide symptom relief, they do not prevent recurrence and may impair long-term tendon healing.  Surgical intervention is considered only after a prolonged (6-12 months) trial of nonoperative intervention.  Surgery may involve debridement of degenerated tendon tissue or tendon release.

Prognosis



In most patients, conservative treatment is successful, although resolution can take 6-12 months.  Symptoms may recur if strengthening exercises and activity modifications are not consistently maintained.

Prevention



Prevention strategies include regular forearm strengthening and stretching, a gradual increase in activity, and proper ergonomics and technique when participating in sports or repetitive activities.

Summary



Elbow tendinopathy is a common overuse injury caused by repetitive, forceful wrist extension or flexion.  It involves microtrauma and degeneration of the wrist extensor tendons (lateral epicondylitis) or flexor tendons (medial epicondylitis) at their origin on the humeral epicondyles.  Diagnosis is clinical, and the mainstays of treatment include activity modification, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, counterforce bracing, and physical therapy.
